Title: Cute Determinant Question
Content:
I stumbled across the following problem and found it cute. Problem: We are given that $19$ divides $23028$, $31882$, $86469$, $6327$, and $61902$. Show that $19$ divides the following determinant: $$\left|
 \begin{matrix}
  2 & 3&0&2&8 \\
  3 & 1&8&8&2\\
8&6&4&6&9\\
0&6&3&2&7\\
6&1&9&0&2
 \end{matrix}\right|$$
AcceptedAnswer: Multiply the first column by $10^4$, the second by $10^3$, third by $10^2$ and fourth by $10$ - this will scale the value of the determinant by $10^{4+3+2+1}=10^{10}$, which is coprime to $19$. Now add the last four columns to the first one - this will not change the value of the determinant. Finally notice the first column now reads $23028, 31882, 86469, 6327$, and $61902$: each is a multiple of $19$ so we can factor a nineteen cleanly out the determinant.

Solution_for_new_problem:
Let M be the given 5×5 matrix with rows r₁, r₂, r₃, r₄, r₅. Each row rᵢ = [aᵢ, bᵢ, cᵢ, dᵢ, eᵢ] forms a 5-digit number Nᵢ = 10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ that is divisible by 19 by assumption. Thus for each i:
10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ ≡ 0 (mod 19)

Define the vector v = [10000, 1000, 100, 10, 1] modulo 19. Then for each row rᵢ:
v·rᵢᵀ = 10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ ≡ 0 (mod 19)

Thus v is a non-zero vector (since its entries are not all 0 modulo 19) in the left nullspace of M modulo 19. This means M is singular modulo 19, i.e., det(M) ≡ 0 (mod 19). Therefore, 19 divides det(M).

Verification: We can check that v = [10000, 1000, 100, 10, 1] ≡ [5, 12, 5, 10, 1] (mod 19) since 10000 ≡ 5, 1000 ≡ 12, 100 ≡ 5 (mod 19). For each row, the dot product with v modulo 19 equals the 5-digit number modulo 19, which is 0 by assumption.

Assumption 5: The fourth row is 0, 6, 3, 2, 7 (forming 06327 or 6327)

Problem:
Show that 19 divides the determinant of the matrix:
$$
\left|
 \begin{matrix}
  2 & 3 & 0 & 2 & 8 \\
  3 & 1 & 8 & 8 & 2 \\
  8 & 6 & 4 & 6 & 9 \\
  0 & 6 & 3 & 2 & 7 \\
  6 & 1 & 9 & 0 & 2
 \end{matrix}\right|.
$$
Let M be the 5×5 matrix with rows r₁, r₂, r₃, r₄, r₅, where each rᵢ = [aᵢ, bᵢ, cᵢ, dᵢ, eᵢ] ∈ ℤ⁵. The condition that each row forms a 5-digit number divisible by 19 means:

For each i = 1,...,5:
10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ ≡ 0 (mod 19).

Define the vector v = [10000, 1000, 100, 10, 1] ∈ ℤ⁵. Working modulo 19, we compute:

v·rᵢᵀ = 10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ ≡ 0 (mod 19) for each i = 1,...,5.

This means that vM ≡ 0 (mod 19) when considered as a row vector multiplying the matrix M. In other words, v is a non-zero vector in the left nullspace of M modulo 19.

Since v ≠ 0 (mod 19) (as 10000, 1000, 100, 10, 1 are not all divisible by 19), this shows that M has a non-trivial left nullspace when considered as a matrix over the field ℤ/19ℤ. A matrix over a field has a non-trivial left nullspace if and only if it is singular (i.e., has determinant 0).

Therefore, det(M) ≡ 0 (mod 19) when considered modulo 19. Since det(M) is an integer, this means 19 divides det(M).

More formally:
1. Let M be the 5×5 integer matrix with rows r₁,...,r₅.
2. Define v = [10000, 1000, 100, 10, 1].
3. For each i, v·rᵢᵀ = 10000aᵢ + 1000bᵢ + 100cᵢ + 10dᵢ + eᵢ ≡ 0 (mod 19) by hypothesis.
4. Thus vM ≡ 0 (mod 19) as a row vector.
5. Since v ≠ 0 (mod 19), M has a non-trivial left nullspace over ℤ/19ℤ.
6. A matrix over a field is singular if and only if it has a non-trivial left nullspace.
7. Therefore, M is singular modulo 19, so det(M) ≡ 0 (mod 19).
8. Hence 19 divides the integer det(M).

This completes the proof.
